title: Prayer timeout
data:
Your **prayer timeout** is the amount of time you need to wait before your [god](/wiki/God "God") will accept another [prayer](/wiki/Prayer "Prayer"). Gods in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")* are often benevolent, but prefer if you wait some time between prayers. The initial value of your prayer timeout is set to 300, and decreases by one each game [turn](/wiki/Turn "Turn"). That means it is generally safe to pray on turn 301, but not on 300. If you are [fast](/wiki/Fast "Fast") or very fast, you may move more than once per game turn, and your prayer timeout may appear longer because you take more actions in the same number of game turns. A [wand](/wiki/Wand_of_enlightenment "Wand of enlightenment") or [potion of enlightenment](/wiki/Potion_of_enlightenment "Potion of enlightenment") can be used to determine if it is safe to pray.

The exact amount to which your prayer timeout is set after praying is a [complex mathematical function](/wiki/Rnz "Rnz") involving several random variables, causing the timeout to *usually* range between 50 and 1000, though it can be much higher on occasion (see the tables below for precise numbers).

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Trouble](#Trouble)
- [2 Praying](#Praying)
- [3 Wishing](#Wishing)
- [4 Sacrificing corpse](#Sacrificing_corpse)
- [5 Typical prayer timeouts](#Typical_prayer_timeouts)
- [6 References](#References)

## Trouble

If you are experiencing a major [trouble](/wiki/Trouble "Trouble"), Gods will accept your prayer if your timeout is less than 201. If you are experiencing a minor trouble, Gods will accept your prayer if your timeout is less than 101. Since your prayer timeout is reset after prayer (as opposed to increased), if deliberately praying for an increase in max [HP](/wiki/HP "HP") at the start of the game, it's better to do this on turn 101 than 301.

In the typical early game state (Gods are pleased, you are not crowned, and you are not in the endgame), there is a \~22% chance that your prayer timeout will be reset to less than 201. That means that there is a chance to successfully pray for major trouble help on consecutive turns (perhaps if a [cockatrice](/wiki/Cockatrice "Cockatrice") is hissing at you during a [new moon](/wiki/New_moon "New moon") and you have no better option).

Enlightenment's message regarding safe prayer does account for your trouble status. That means that the message might say that it's safe to pray when your HP is low, but when your HP improves it becomes unsafe to pray due to a still positive prayer timeout.

## Praying

Your prayer timeout is reset by praying. The amount it is reset to is significantly increased if you have:

- have been [crowned](/wiki/Crowned "Crowned")[\[1\]](#cite_note-1).
- killed the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") or have performed the [invocation](/wiki/Invocation "Invocation")[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3).

Also your prayer timeout may be incremented further if you've done any of the following actions:

- Being converted to another [alignment](/wiki/Align "Align") through cross-aligned [sacrifice](/wiki/Sacrifice "Sacrifice")
- Praying at an [altar](/wiki/Altar "Altar") not of your alignment

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

If the game goes on longer than 100 000 turns, the prayer timeout after successfully praying is now increased by 1 turn per 100 turns beyond that time. This is to counter denial of service on public servers by pasting the same commands indefinitely.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

## Wishing

A successful [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish") increases your prayer timeout. The 95% confidence value is an additional 145 turns and the 100% confidence value is 150 turns. See below for more information on confidence values.

## Sacrificing corpse

The only way to decrease your prayer timeout (other than waiting) is to [sacrifice](/wiki/Sacrifice "Sacrifice") [corpses](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") at a co-aligned altar. This is governed by the following formula which depends on your alignment.

- Chaotic: ![\frac{M \times 500}{24}](/images/math/b/7/f/b7fbfeefee42f53741071e5e57f922eb.png)

* Lawful and neutral: ![\frac{M \times 300}{24}](/images/math/3/2/9/329d57776d801496c0dc48efee469891.png)

Where `M` is the [difficulty level](/wiki/Monsters_\(by_difficulty\) "Monsters (by difficulty)") of the monster the corpse came from. The value from above is then subtracted from your prayer timeout. You can determine if it is safe to pray depending on what [message you received](/wiki/Sacrifice#Prayer_timeouts_and_sacrifice "Sacrifice") after your sacrifice.

## Typical prayer timeouts

The confidence value is the prayer timeout value that will result 95% of the time. In other words, if you've waited that many [turns](/wiki/Turns "Turns"), you can be 95% confident that you can pray again. As you can see, the 100% confidence value is extremely large and fairly useless except for those who fear the [RNG](/wiki/RNG "RNG"). (Amusingly, for crowned characters, praying too early may actually shorten the prayer timeout.)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7](/wiki/NetHack_3.7 "NetHack 3.7")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Prior to [commit dde1ae2e](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/dde1ae2e9bf8ed6500e088a6c5f5d9adbb1b93c5), being smited by a god would unconditionally set prayer timeout to rnz(300), possibly making it shorter than the existing timeout, especially for a crowned character. Being smited now sets the prayer timeout to whichever is greater: the existing prayer timeout, or rnz(300).

| Prayer                                                                                 | 95% confidence | 100% confidence if XL ≤ 17 | 100% confidence at XL 30 |
| -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------- | -------------------------- | ------------------------ |
| God is displeased                                                                      | 1053           | 2998                       | 5997                     |
| God is pleased                                                                         | 1229           | 3498                       | 6996                     |
| God is pleased, and you've been crowned OR are a [demigod](/wiki/Demigod "Demigod")\*  | 3980           | 13493                      | 26986                    |
| God is pleased, and you've been crowned AND are a [demigod](/wiki/Demigod "Demigod")\* | 7479           | 23488                      | 46976                    |

\*This refers to having killed the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") or performed the [invocation ritual](/wiki/Invocation_ritual "Invocation ritual").

The waiting time is graphed below as a function of the desired confidence level (assuming you are level 17 or lower):

- [![](/images/thumb/1/11/PrayerTimeoutConfidenceHappy95.svg/100px-PrayerTimeoutConfidenceHappy95.svg.png)](/wiki/File:PrayerTimeoutConfidenceHappy95.svg)

  Pleased, zoom 95-100%

- [![](/images/thumb/4/48/PrayerTimeoutConfidenceHappy.svg/100px-PrayerTimeoutConfidenceHappy.svg.png)](/wiki/File:PrayerTimeoutConfidenceHappy.svg)

  Pleased

- [![](/images/thumb/5/51/PrayerTimeoutConfidenceCrowned.svg/100px-PrayerTimeoutConfidenceCrowned.svg.png)](/wiki/File:PrayerTimeoutConfidenceCrowned.svg)

  Pleased, crowned

- [![](/images/thumb/1/1e/PrayerTimeoutConfidenceBoth.svg/100px-PrayerTimeoutConfidenceBoth.svg.png)](/wiki/File:PrayerTimeoutConfidenceBoth.svg)

  Pleased, crowned & Rodney

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [pray.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 1019](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/pray.c#line1019 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/pray.c")
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [spell.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 255](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/spell.c#line255 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/spell.c")
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [wizard.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 550](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/wizard.c#line550 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/wizard.c")
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) <https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/0968d06>
